Location: Asia, with smaller numbers native to Europe, North America, and northwestern Africa
Information: Rose is mainly used in commercial and medicinal purposes. It treats skin diseases, eye strain, stress, insomnia, diarrhea and hyperacidity.
Procuder:
Herbal Tea:Preparation: Collect fresh rose leaves or use dried rose leaves.

Infusion: Steep the rose leaves in hot water to make a herbal tea.

Consumption: Drink the rose leaf tea regularly to benefit from its medicinal properties. It can help alleviate stress, promote relaxation, and improve sleep quality.

Topical Application for Skin Diseases:Paste: Crush fresh rose leaves into a paste or boil them to extract the juice.

Application to Skin: Apply the paste or juice directly to the affected areas of the skin to treat skin diseases. The anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties of rose leaves can help reduce inflammation and fight infections.

Eye Strain Relief:

Eye Compress: Boil rose leaves in water to make an herbal infusion. Allow it to cool.

Application to Eyes: Soak a clean cloth or cotton pads in the cooled rose leaf infusion and place them over closed eyes. This can help relieve eye strain and refresh tired eyes
